references: Note that numerous studies show that the imbalance of a dataset causes performance degradation Huang et al. (2021); Lin et al. (2023); Li and Shi (2021). In order to demonstrate whether the dataset is created evenly, we conduct statistical analysis by comparing ChatLang-8 with existing datasets. Figure 3 shows a subject distribution of ChatLang-8. We observe that the distribution of subject types in ChatLang-8 is evenly distributed. It suggests that the Subject Selector and evaluator affect data quality improvement even though the evaluator abandons all unsuitable data. In Figure 4 and Table 5, we find that the grammar types of ChatLang-8 are most evenly distributed while the other corpora have highly unbalanced grammar labels. For example, W&I+LOCNESS dataset has 10.7% (averaged) of Determiner (DET) errors, and 17.75% of Punctuation (PUNCT) errors, whereas 0.6133% of Conjunction (CONJ) and 0.21% of Adjective Form (ADJ:FORM). Existing datasets have a very small proportion of important grammatical patterns, which can cause performance degradation during model training. In addition, since ChatLang-8 excluded OTHER and UNK labels when generating data, while the other corpora have a great proportion of UNK label (e.g., NUCLE: 25.65%) and OTHER label (e.g., NUCLE: 2.57%), it is easier to handle dataset and to predict the model outputs.

Figure 2 shows an example and its corresponding M2 outputs, which qualitatively demonstrate the effect of dataset used for training, as shown in Section 3.2. We observe that the learned model using ChatLang-8 can detect and correct multiple errors including punctuation (PUNCT), orthography (ORTH), and conjunction (CONJ) while its opponent can not find any errors. Indeed, the output of model learned with ChatLang-8 is In India, we have various types of public transport, like Cycle, Bike, Car, Train, and Flight. Results in Figure 2 demonstrates that ChatLang-8 has the error distribution shown in Table 5 very well, and thereby efficiently helps the learning of the GEC system.

Factuality and Morality. Though ChatLang-8 effectively can reflect a distribution of human-like grammatical errors in Figure 5 and guide a GEC model to perform well, due to uniform randomness of our method to encourage diversity, sometimes generated pairs have information that is literally not true. For instance, in Section 2.1, Subject Selector, of course, can generate celebrity (e.g., Michael Jackson or Taylor Swift), or even company name (e.g., Google or Amazon). By combining the selected subject and grammatical information, sentences that are not true can be generated as follows:

Table 5 shows the ERRANT error type distributions of ChatLang-8 and The Other Corpora. We find that ChatLang-8 are most evenly distributed while the other corpora have highly unbalanced grammar labels.

references: One naive approach is to design the prompt to generate pairs without considering the subject element. However, as shown in Table 1, when simply generating parallel sentences, the type of subject of the sentence becomes too limited. To mitigate this risk, we propose Subject Selector (SS), a novel algorithm for diversifying subject S𝑆S of parallel sentences. First, we predefine the type of subject Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k} to be created111Predefined types: Common Noun, Proper Noun, Collective Noun, Compound Noun, Concrete Noun, Abstract Noun, Countable Noun, and Uncountable Noun.. Then Subject Selector randomly choose a type of subject Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k} among the predefined noun types and generate subject candidates as large as the window size. For example, if the noun type selected by Subject Selector is proper noun and the window size is 30, 30 proper nouns are created. Then, one of the candidates is randomly determine as a subject of a sentence.

Prompt (✙ GS) {’The…the’: 6, ’Neither…nor’: 6, ’Both…and’: 4, ’So’: 4, ’While’: 4, ’When’: 3, ’So…that:’: 3, ’Yet’: 3, ’Rather…than’: 3, ’Now that’: 3, ’And’: 3, ’But’: 3, ’As’: 3, ’Nor’: 2, ’Before’: 2, ’As soon as’: 2, ’As long as’: 2, ’As well as’: 2, ’Either…or’: 2, ’Even if’: 2, ’If’: 2, ’Or’: 2, ’Although’: 2, ’Hardly…when’: 1, ’Because’: 1, ’In case’: 1, ’Once’: 1, ’Not…but’: 1, ’Besides’: 1, ’Since’: 1, ’Whether…or’: 1, ’If…then’: 1, ’As many…as’: 1, ’So that’: 1, ’Not so…as’: 1, ’Supposing’: 1, ’Not only…but also’: 1, ’Provided that’: 1, ’For’: 1, ’Till’: 1, ’Even though’: 1, ’Too…to’: 1, ’Nonetheless’: 1, ’As…as’: 1, ’By the time’: 1, ’Still’: 1, ’Even if’: 1, ’No sooner…than’: 1, ’That’: 1, ’Scarcely…when’: 1, ’In order to’: 1, ’If only’: 1, ’Indeed’: 1, ’Otherwise’: 1, ’Though’: 1}
references: Similar to the problem in Section 2.1, a vanilla prompt to generate pairs of wrong and correct sentences produces an extremely constrained set of sentences. Table 2 shows that the method just specifying the grammar type also could not ameliorate this problem. For instance, when generating data related to Conjunction, most of the outputs consist of And, and But. In this paper, we propose Grammar Selector (GS) to consider various grammar errors G𝐺G and thereby improve the quality of generated data. We take into account the same grammatical error categories Glsubscript𝐺𝑙G_{l} in Bryant et al. (2017, 2019). Unlike Subject Selector in Section 2.1, Grammar Selector first divides the grammar errors into two types: Errors that require diversification of grammar types and those that do not. For example, Word Order (WO) and Spelling (SPELL) don’t need to consider patterns as large as the window size: We can get good results just by instructing the LLM to create representative of real human errors.

references: Our implementation utilizes GPT-3.5 Turbo. We gathered approximately 1M pairs that cover eight subject type and 23 grammar type. Table 3 shows statistics of ChatLang-8 (ours), FCE Yannakoudakis et al. (2011), Lang-8 Mizumoto et al. (2012); Tajiri et al. (2012), NUCLE Dahlmeier et al. (2013) and W&I+LOCNESS Bryant et al. (2019). Note that we leverage ChatLang-8 that has a corpus size similar to Lang-8, one of the largest GEC corpus, and much larger than the other corpora.

references: To investigate whether ChatLang-8 has value as a dataset, we train a vanilla Transformer Vaswani et al. (2017) and BART Lewis et al. (2020), much larger model, on both ChatLang-8 and Lang-8 Mizumoto et al. (2012); Tajiri et al. (2012). Note that for the fairness of the experiment, we choose Lang-8, which has a similar dataset structure and corpus size, and which effectively improve performance Lichtarge et al. (2019, 2020); Flachs et al. (2021). In addition, though there is previous attempt to improve the Lang-8 Flachs et al. (2021), it reports only five error types on BEA test while we considers 25 error types and three benchmarks. Thus, we employ Lang-8 to the experiments, instead of cLang-8. We evaluate performance on three popular GEC benchmarks: CoNLL-2014 Ng et al. (2014), BEA-2019 Bryant et al. (2019), and GMEG-wiki Napoles et al. (2019). As evaluation metrics, we use M2 scorer Dahlmeier and Ng (2012) for CoNLL-2014, and ERRANT Bryant et al. (2017) for BEA-2019 and GMEG-wiki. Table 4 shows that GEC models trained on ChatLang-8 can surpass its counterparts which are trained on Lang-8 corpus, by a large margin in both recall (R) and F0.5. It represents that the GEC system trained with ChatLang-8 can simultaneously detect multiple types grammatical errors in a sentence and correct them, while system trained with Lang-8 can’t. Simply a high R and a low F0.5 indicate overcorrection. We observe that transformer learned with Lang-8 shows higher precision (P) than its counterpart on CoNLL-2014 and BEA-2019 benchmark evaluations, entailing much lower F0.5. This means that it corrects only very obvious grammatical errors and leaves the rest uncorrected. We also find that leveraging a high-quality GEC corpus is overarching problem, as merely enlarging the model does not always ensure improved performance.
